senses.de: To separate into parts or groups
senses.ex: She divided the cake into eight pieces.

Tips.title: Share Equally
Tips.description: When dividing something like food or items, fairness is often the goal.
Tips.example: Let's divide these cookies equally so everyone gets the same amount.

Tips.title: Not Always Equal
Tips.description: Divide can imply unequal parts based on specific criteria or needs.
Tips.example: He divided the profits according to each partner's investment.

senses.de: To make a clear difference between people or things
senses.ex: Income divides the rich from the poor.

Tips.title: Clear Distinction
Tips.description: To divide sometimes means to distinguish clearly, showing differences.
Tips.example: Their opinions on climate change divide them sharply.

Tips.title: Social Context
Tips.description: Divide can refer to societal differences, often sensitive topics.
Tips.example: Language can create a divide in multicultural societies.

senses.de: To do a mathematical operation to find out how many times one number fits into another
senses.ex: If you divide 20 by 5, the result is 4.

Tips.title: Mathematical Operation
Tips.description: In math, divide is a precise operation, not just splitting into parts.
Tips.example: Can you divide this number by three without using a calculator?

Tips.title: Math Word Problems
Tips.description: In math contexts, 'divide' often signals how to solve word problems.
Tips.example: To find out how many teams we can form, divide the total number of players by 5.

senses.de: a difference or disagreement between two groups that makes communication difficult
senses.ex: There is a huge divide between rich and poor in this city.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Gap
Tips.description: As a noun, 'divide' can symbolize a large gap, not just a physical one.
Tips.example: The digital divide affects people's access to technology.

Tips.title: Emotional Disconnect
Tips.description: Can describe emotional separation between individuals or groups.
Tips.example: Their political views have created a divide in the family.

senses.ex: The river divides the town from the rest of the province.

Tips.title: Geographical Feature
Tips.description: Can describe physical landmarks that separate different areas.
Tips.example: A mountain range divides the two countries.

Tips.title: Boundary Creation
Tips.description: Often used to talk about creating visible or invisible boundaries.
Tips.example: The curtains divide the room into two separate spaces.

senses.de: When cells divide, they split and become two cells
senses.ex: The bacteria divide rapidly under favorable conditions.

Tips.title: Biological Process
Tips.description: In biology, divide refers to cell division, a natural growth process.
Tips.example: Simple organisms can reproduce when they divide.

Tips.title: Speed of Division
Tips.description: The rate of cell division can imply health or environmental conditions.
Tips.example: Under stress, some cells may divide more slowly.

Bifurcate.wordDefinition:
Both bifurcate and divide mean to separate or split something into two or more parts, but they are used in slightly different contexts.

Bifurcate is more commonly used when describing a splitting or branching off into two distinct paths or directions. For example, a river could bifurcate into two streams.

Bifurcate is also often used in scientific or technical contexts to describe a more precise form of dividing, such as in biology when describing a nerve that splits into two smaller nerves.

For example, you might divide a pizza into slices or divide chores among family members. Divide often connotes a more equal or even split, while bifurcate suggests a more asymmetrical or distinct separation.

Break up.wordDefinition:
Break up means to separate into smaller pieces or parts, usually in a sudden or violent way.

Both words can be used in a variety of contexts, but break up is typically used for more dramatic or emotional separations, while divide is used for more practical and logical separations.

Cleave.wordDefinition:
Cleave means to split something into two parts, but often implies doing so with force or strength. For example, a lumberjack might cleave a log in half with an axe.

In everyday use, cleave is less common than divide and tends to be used in contexts where a physical object is being split apart.

Disconnect.wordDefinition:
Disconnect means to separate something that was previously connected or attached. For example, if you unplug your phone from the charger, you are disconnecting it.

Disconnect means to physically or emotionally separate, while divide means to split something into parts.

Disunite.wordDefinition:
Disunite means to cause people or things to separate from each other or to break apart. For example, a disagreement between friends could disunite them, causing them to stop talking and spending time together.

Both words involve separating or breaking apart, but disunite usually refers to people or relationships, while divide refers to objects or quantities.

For a 15-year-old, it could be helpful to think of disunite as involving emotions and divide as involving physical objects or concepts like math problems.

Isolate.wordDefinition:
Isolate means to separate or set something apart from everything else, typically for the purpose of protection, containment or diagnosis.

For example, if someone is sick with a contagious disease, they may need to be isolated to prevent others from getting sick.

In simpler terms, divide means to separate into smaller groups, while isolate means to separate or separate a single thing from everything else.

Divide is applicable when you want to break down a larger group into smaller ones, while isolate is used when you want to separate something from the rest for a specific reason.

Partition.wordDefinition:
Both divide and partition mean to separate something into parts.

Partition implies a more deliberate and structured separation of something into specific parts that may be more equal or distinct from each other.

For example, you might partition a room into separate areas for different purposes, or partition a hard drive into separate sections for different types of files.

Separate.wordDefinition:
Divide means to break something into parts or portions, while separate means to set apart, detach, or isolate something.

For example, we divide an apple into equal pieces to share it among friends. On the other hand, we separate two different types of fruits or vegetables to store them separately as they may spoil each other.

Divide is used when we want to allocate or distribute something, while separate is used when we want to isolate or distinguish something.

Sever.wordDefinition:
Sever means to cut or break something apart completely. It's used to indicate a more forceful or permanent separation, such as severing a limb or severing ties with someone.

Divide is used for dividing something into smaller parts or sections, while sever is used for cutting something apart completely or permanently.

Split.wordDefinition:
The words divide and split both mean to break something into smaller pieces, but they're used in slightly different ways.

Split is used when something is being separated or divided in a more general sense. For instance, you might split a piece of wood in two with a saw, or split a sandwich with a friend.

So while the words can be used somewhat interchangeably, divide implies a more even or measured distribution, while split is more general and can refer to any kind of breaking apart.

quotes.Text: Life is divided into three terms - that which was, which is, and which will be. Let us learn from the past to profit by the present, and from the present, to live better in the future.
quotes.Title: English Poet
quotes.Name: William Wordsworth

quotes.Text: I really feel sorry for people who are, who divide their whole life up into 'things that I like' and 'things that I must do.' You're only here for a short time, mate. Learn to like it.
quotes.Title: Australian Actor
quotes.Name: Russell Crowe

quotes.Text: The national team has always lent its image to help Italy's problems over the years... The national team is more about uniting than dividing.
quotes.Title: Italian Athlete
quotes.Name: Fabio Cannavaro

quotes.Text: The word career is a divisive word. It's a word that divides the normal life from business or professional life.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Grace Paley

quotes.Text: I like to cross the divide between the personal world and the scientific world.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Temple Grandin

quotes.Text: My life and career can be divided into pre- and post- 'Paruthiveeran.
quotes.Title: Indian Actress
quotes.Name: Priyamani

quotes.Text: The way politics divides the world is into friend and enemy.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Francis Parker Yockey

quotes.Text: Life is divided into the horrible and the miserable.
quotes.Title: American Director
quotes.Name: Woody Allen

quotes.Text: All of the universe will be divided into two parts.
quotes.Title: American Explorer
quotes.Name: Jeff Rich

quotes.Text: You can divide my life into two.
quotes.Title: British Soldier
quotes.Name: Lord Mountbatten
